The first numeration system

In the first class (History Tracers, 2024), we studied the inspiration to the first numerical system were our fingers. We also observe that to use fingers has an "issue" to reach a limit of objects that we can enumerate, independent to have other people helping. The initial solution was representing our fingers like pipes (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., 2010, pp. 174 - 177, 180 - 182):

Figure 1: Representation of baboon bone with markings. This image was made by Enrique Silván Pobes, and it can be found in the work of Francisco A. Gonzáles Redondo et al..
The original is available in ResearchNet (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., 2010) and it is shown here after Doctor Francisco A. Gonzales Redondo authorized its republication.

In the past centuries different numeration systems were used, we show here some used nowadays and other left behind recently.

Understanding the limits

The limit idea is a fundamental part of the sciences, this is the reason we explain it before the numerical systems.

When we enumerate with the hands, we have as the limit the amount of fingers, so the limit represents the maximum value.

The limit idea is also present in descending enumeration. Returning to fruit collection example of the first class (History Tracers, 2024). Le us suppose that you put all collected fruits on the "table", now raise your fingers for each collected fruit. Every time a person gets a fruit, you will put a finger down. When all fruits were got, you will not have fingers up. In this example, we moved in direction of a new limit, that reaches the minimum possible, that means do not have fruits.

The limit is present everywhere, so we understand limit as a value that will be reached for a studied scenario.

Some decimal numerical systems

Despite the first numerical representation were made around 30000 years (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., 2010, pp. 174 - 177, 180 - 182), the numbers used nowadays in Western world were made millennia later (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 48 - 53), but this was not the unique numerical system created in the past millennia. In the Andes region we had the quipus development, that were used by Inca to represent numerical and nonnumerical data (Zavala, José Manuel, et al, 2021 ; Rojas Leiva, Alejo, 2016, pp. 2), but they did not make it.

Figure 2: Quipu representation. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers, 2024).

The Huari people used quipus (Rojas Leiva, Alejo, 2016, pp. 2 ; Conklin, William J., 1987, pp. 154 - 158), and it is also possible that Caral used it 5000 years ago (Bobbio Rosas, Emilio Gustavo, 2016, pp. 82), but there is not consensus about this (Mann, Charles C., 2005, pp. 1008 - 1009).

The Mesoamerican system

In Mesoamerica, region between Mexico northern and Costa Rica northern (Kilroy-Ewbank, Lauren Dr.), it is also possible to arrive in the conclusion they used fingers to make their numerical system, but instead to use only fingers, they also used toes to make a vigesimal system (Marcus, Joyce, 2000).

The zero

The number zero is fundamental nowadays, but its discover is relatively new (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 44, 46 - 48). Despite the zero to be "discovered" in different places of the world, according to Auwalu Musa, and Anna Blume confirms, it is not possible to say that Maya people had the same concept, at least we have new ancient text to modify this (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 61 - 62).

Selecting the symbols

When we use only a symbol to represent the numbers, like the pipe ( | ), we can create confusion to the readers, for example, when readers do not understand the number we wrote, because the separation was not clear. To solve this issue, the modern numerical systems follow the characteristics:
  1. They have one symbol for each finger of our hands.
  2. The first number represents the idea of empty (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 46)
  3. When it is not possible to represent the enumeration with only one symbol, we add another symbol to its side.
In this class, we are going to study the first two characteristics using our fingers:

Figure 3: Fingers of a left hand: A - Thumb, B - Index, C - Middle, D - Ring, E - Little. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers, 2024).

Conclusion

In this class, we studied how are fingers and toes can be associated with decimal numerical systems used in the recent millennia. We also explored two characteristics of these numerical systems.

In next class we will study the numerical sequence and studying more about limits.
